awd_titl_txt: Developing Efficient and Accessible Computational Tools for Poroelasticity Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
Poroelasticity problems arise from a broad range of real world problems, in which fluid flows through a porous medium that can deform due to the fluid pressure.  For example, convection-enhanced drug delivery to tumor sites, functioning of knee meniscus, and CO2 sequestration all involve this type of interaction between solid (displacement) and fluid (pressure).  Mathematical modeling and computer simulations will provide valuable tools to enhance our ability in understanding, predicting, and controlling these complicated physical processes.  This research project aims at developing a family of novel accurate, efficient, and robust numerical methods for poroelasticity problems.
    
The focus of this project is on design, analysis, implementation, and applications of a family of novel finite element methods for poroelasticity problems.  Based on the displacement-pressure two-field formulation, weak Galerkin finite element methods will be developed for approximating both solid displacement and fluid pressure.  Conditions for stable coupling of these sub-problem solvers will be investigated.  The new methods will be applied to an engineering problem on knee meniscus. These new methods will also be implemented as Matlab and C++ code modules (on deal.II platform) that are openly accessible to the scientific computing community. The efficient and robust computational tools developed in this project can be applied to many real world problems that involve poroelasticity such as drug delivery to tumor sites, food processing, reservoir engineering, and tissue engineering.  These will have further economic impact on better use of natural resources or cures for diseases.  The methodology developed in this project can be applied to a large class of scientific computing tasks that deal with multiple physical processes.  This project will also provide hands-on training opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project has produced a set of efficient and robust novel numerical methods for solving poroelasticity problems that are modelled by coupled equations for Darcy flow and elasticity.  As fluid flows through a deformable porous medium, the fluid pressure affects the medium deformation and simultaneously the deformation affects also the flow.  Such interaction poses challenges to numerical solvers for this type of problems which occur often in natural processes and engineering practices, e.g., drug delivery, food processing, petroleum reservoir simulation, and tissue engineering.   

Through careful analysis, the PI and collaborators have designed a set of accurate and efficient finite element methods for the aforementioned poroelasticity problems.  These methods have been rigorously analyzed for their accuracy and robustness.  These new methods have also been implemented in our two code packages: DarcyLite (in Matlab) and Darcy+ (in C++), which are openly accessible to the scientific community.  

The project has produced 10 research papers in journals and proceedings, trained 3 graduate students (2 Ph.D., 1 master) to graduation, and 1 postdoc research associate.  Additionally, 18 talks were given by the PI in seminars and conferences.  The two software packages (DarcyLite, Darcy+) maintained by the PI have been further enriched with Matlab and C++ code modues for the new methods developed for this project.

The methodology developed in this project can be applied to a large class of scientific computing tasks that deal with multiple physical processes.  The code packages/modules have been adopted for teaching at the graduate level.



Last Modified: 11/04/2022
Modified by: Jiangguo Liu
